captions.text:
All stories are built on the stories that
came before them. It is a simple truth

that resonates with every good storyteller.
The most fascinating fantasy and sci-fi settings
are oftentimes derivative of our own world, and as a result, our favorite fictional

stories are often inspired by real world people
and events. You have played the games, but

you probably overlooked the countless historical
and literary references contained within them.

References to our own world; references that
blur the line between fiction and our own

reality. Join us, as we unlock the deep unseen
histories of Fallout in this first edition
of Hidden History.
The main protagonist you play as in Fallout 3

was born on 7/13/2258, which is thought
to be a biblical reference to this verse,

and of course it aptly describes the Fallout
series.

You almost certainly knew that Fallout heavily
draws its themes from our world; with settings

like Washington DC and Las Vegas, it’s impossible
to overlook where this franchise takes its

inspiration from. One Fallout enthusiast from
the UK went as far as to visit the American

Southwest. And his mission? To take a pilgrim
where he would uncover Fallout’s real world

locations and props. What you’re seeing
now is only a few of his findings.

Visit a location called the “Temple of the
Union” in Fallout 3, and you’ll find escaped

slaves who are looking to restore the Lincoln
Memorial in post-nuclear DC. They want to

make this war-torn Memorial a sanctuary for
other escaped slaves. But did you realize

that these NPCs are named after real life
members of Abraham Lincoln’s administration,

who served during the American Civil War?
The same war that abolished slavery in the
United States in 1865. Funnier still, you’ll encounter

an NPC by name of Leroy Walker, a slaver who
will tell you how much he hates the runaway

slaves hiding at the Temple of the Union.
This slave trader is named after LeRoy Pope

Walker, the first Secretary of War who served
under the Confederacy.

Robert Edwin House, or Mr. House as he’s
more commonly known, is the perfect picture

of the American industrialist, but did you
ever notice that his persona parallels that

of Howard Hughes, a real life American business
tycoon of the 20th century? This is most readily

seen in their portraits here; where Hughes
is pictured standing in front of a WWI military

aircraft. Robert House is mirroring him in
turn, by standing in front of Liberty Prime,

the colossal American war machine featured
in Fallout 3.

Many of you probably already knew that, but
the historical comparisons don’t stop there.

House’s robot girlfriend, Jane, is thought
to have been inspired by the 1950s film star

Jane Russell, who was an actress and known
lover of Howard Hughes. On a similar note,

Mr. House was supposed to have another Securitron
girl named Marilyn who was apparently cut

from the game before its release. It’s a
fair assumption to say that Marilyn was most

likely a reference to the 50s film actress
Marilyn Monroe.

There were other robots found in the Fallout
universe that referenced real world people

as well, some more obvious than others. You
might have met the wig wearing protectron

located in the National Archives, and recognized
his name as Button Gwinnett, a historical

signer of the Declaration of Independence.
In fact, this robot thinks he is the real

Button Gwinnet who died in 1777. And if you
ever tried killing him, he’ll say this...

This is a reference to the Revolutionary War
hero Nathan Hale, who said the same thing

before he was hung by the British in 1776.
Other robots are a bit more subtle about their

historical references, so subtle in fact you
most likely missed them entirely.

President John Henry Eden's propaganda eyebots,
that endless playback those infamous broadcasts

on Enclave Radio, are rumored to be loosely
based on similar broadcasts made by US President

Franklin D. Roosevelt during the Great Depression.
These real world radio broadcasts were a series

of thirty evening radio addresses given by
the President between 1933 and 1944.
Are you a fan of the soft drinks found littering the Wasteland?
I know that you already know that Nuka Cola is a clear reference to Coca-Cola;

however, what you probably didn’t know is
that in the Fallout universe, Nuka-Cola’s

founder is named John-Caleb Bradberton. A
curious name indeed, considering it is a combination

of the names John Pemberton, and Caleb Bradham,
the actual inventors of- you guessed it...

Frank Horrigan, the main antagonist and final
boss in Fallout 2, is the Enclave's finest

weapon. Originally a Secret Service Agent
for Enclave President Dick Richardson, he

has since been twisted into a super mutant
by the F.E.V.

Frank Horrigan was actually named after Clint
Eastwood's character in the film In the Line

of Fire. The Frank Horrigan from the film
was also a secret service agent whose task

was to protect the US president. And of course,
fans of the second game will probably remember

Frank Horrigan’s last words before he dies,
“Semper Fi”.
“Semper Fi” is actually

short for “Semper Fidelis” which is Latin
for "Always Faithful" and the motto of the

United States Marines.
You thought you knew Fallout, but hopefully

you’ve learned just a thing or two more.
However, perhaps you know some Fallout historical

or literary references that we didn’t cover
here. If so, share them in the comment section

below. And if you liked this show and its
format, don’t forget to ‘Like’ and ‘Share’
so we know to make more.
